message: Germany feels like startup desert to me. Most startups that get funded offer something they copy from oversea.
I feel the same way about my hometown in Arizona, USA

Hehe, you're comparing a single town with one of the biggest economies of this whole world. We're trying to get funded currently and are in a pot together with 12 other startups. We had the chance to have a peak at 7 of them and all of them were simple rip-offs of successful american companies. German magazine Computerwoche saw the same problem of risk-shy investors half a year ago. I hate it :-)
this is a good point for sure, I wish you luck in getting funded
Iam from germany.. and yes, we are a startup desert... its the german way of thinking "safe", which leads to often to the conclusion "that won't work" ...
hope not to see you here any more
go away to your german-land. you are not welcome here
bye bye
Where? before the gates of Stalingrad? We didn't have any problems to get that funded back in the day.. those were the times man!

But, on topic: german startups are getting funded just fine. You'll need to find private investors though, people that really want you to succeed, not random VC.

@jfritsch There is a whole page for german startups: http://www.deutsche-startups.de/ ... I think the "startup"-mentality in USA and germany are not compareable.
ger here
Umm... I mean the only innovative startup in the pitch we're currently in ;-)
Na, in dem Fall: https://convore.com/deutscher-chat/

@fx I also don't think we will be having lot of trouble getting funded. Point is that we're probably the only startup with a unique innovative idea and that makes me ashamed of the culture of handling risk here.
Especially for startups in germany and potential founders I would love if you join https://convore.com/deutsche-startups
@jfritsch right now, I'm reading the article you posted
"Are there any germans around?" ... Japs (^_^)
So what are your feelings about german startup culture? @HEbertKONLABS  @tister  @manuw  @jester  @Tasche  @cappa

I have that feeling that most of the american mentality would work just fine in Germany too. German investors most often want the same profits as investors overseas but they are not willing to take a bit of a risk for it.
We're almost funded. But previous offers were just ridiculous attempts at getting our work almost for free. Now we're in serious interviews with an investor.
@jfritsch I can't even count how often I've heard these excuses anymore. No idea what your startup is, but it being a terrible idea is more likely than general unwillingness to take a risk.
@jfritsch good luck then - a good product will always find a buyer. Even in Germany.
@fx When we're successful you will probably never hear from us ;-)
<- another "germ"
@eik3 You probably want to join https://convore.com/deutsche-startups/
I would like to, but convore says: "Sorry, you can only join 20 groups. Please leave another group before attempting to join this one." I think that limit is way too low.
